results.title: Shearing time at Billabong
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Australia’s 120 million sheep are scattered all over the continent wherever there is green grass and water. Billabong Station, in the hot dry interior, depends upon a nearby billabong to supply water to moisten the fertile soil. On the station property 40,000 sheep graze and each summer, shearing at Billabong commences. Gangs of shearers travel from far and wide to work at Billabong. The sheep are mustered by men and their dogs, sent through the drafting yards and into the shearing shed. The wool taken from the shearers is skirted, sorted, and pressed into 300-lb bales - and sent on its way to the sales. After that, Australia’s wool goes to the world.

results.title: [Kodak Cinegraph compilation. No. 08]
results.brief_description: A compilation of newsreel segments focusing on Australia. 1. ‘[Royal Melbourne Zoo]’ shows a family strolling through the zoo. 2. ‘[Nar Nar Goon Airport]’ 3. ‘Turtle Island’ includes footage of giant turtles on the beach, men riding the turtles in a light-hearted race, and a dead turtle being cut open to show its heart which continues to beat 48 hours after death. 4. ‘[Peach growing in Australia]’ captures Australia’s fruit growing and canning industry in the 30’s showing the orchards, the sorting and inspection area, women peeling and removing stones, and the mechanised canning and processing sections.

results.title: [Kodak Cinegraph compilation. No. 12]
results.creator_credit: Commonwealth Government of Australia and Kodak Cinegraph
results.brief_description: A compilation of short newsreel segments. 1. ‘Where traffic is all wet’ captures the hustle and bustle of Shanghai harbour, followed by a Japanese harbour showing a ferry designed to take boats overland and a water tunnel. 2. ‘Glimpses of Australia’ takes a look at seals and penguins on Lady Julia Percy Island located 200 miles from Melbourne. 3. ‘A Glimpse of Canberra’ produced by the Development and Migration Commision visits parliament House. 4. ‘[Melbourne Zoo] shows Jimmy the champanzee, ostriches, tigers, lions, leopards, bears and a novelty segment showing a Mr Wilkie tugging at the tail of an accommodating tiger.

results.title: [Kodak Cinegraph compilation. No. 07]
results.brief_description: A compilation of early silent footage featuring Australian and North American wildlife. Shows kangaroos, wallabies, bandicoots, opossum (including an albino opossum), wombat, koala, Tasmanian devil, platypus and echidna. Also shows footage at a real rodeo in Pendleton, Oregon and a fight betweena cobra and a mongoose.

results.title: Alice in Wonderland
results.creator_credit: Edward H. Sloman, John W. Considine and Gordon W. Hedwig
results.brief_description: This film opens on a theatre full of people. The conductor steps up and the curtains open - music starts. Irving Berlin music introduces characters from Lewis Carrolls’ “Alice in Wonderland”. As the song plays, Alice encounters each character, each elaborately costumed. Once all the characters have been introduced, the song ends; the curtain closes; the audinece applauds. Devised as a film, this piece plays like a number from a vaudeville show.

results.title: Coal
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Advance Australia”.
Elementary account of Australia’s coal industry showing models of coal formations; the principal coal mining areas of Australia; views of Wollongong, Newcastle and Lithgow, centres of coal mining areas; open cut mining at Musellbrook; the uses to which coal is put and some of its principal by-products.

results.title: Pilkington Brothers offer: the best of both worlds
results.creator_credit: Frank Worth, Cecil Musk and British Information Services

video_links.name: Pilkington Brothers offer: the best of both worlds

results.brief_description: Two visitors from outer space visit Earth in order to investigate a material unknown on their planet - glass. They are shown the many architectural uses of glass and the many varieties which are available for use.

results.title: Men in wool
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Designed to show the importance of wool in the manufacture of men’s clothing, tracking the cycle from the shearing shed to the tailored suit. Illustrates the process of shearing, grading, scouring and carding and explains the range of tests for strength, elasticity and possible imperfections. Finally shows the manufacture of a suit using mass productions and hand tailoring techniques. Photographed by George Heath; narrated by Michael Charlton; edited by Les Wasley; script by John Moyes Junior; sound by Allyn Barnes.
